prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

para.paratext: In 1988 Congress gave the Panel power to transfer cases between circuit courts of appeals when multiple appeals are filed from a single administrative agency or board proceeding.[1] The statute requires the Panel to select one of the courts of appeals in which appeals have been filed to be selected randomly by the Panel and to enter an order consolidating all the appeals from that administrative proceeding in that court.[2] The statute also authorizes the Panel to issue rules relating to this new transfer power, and it has done so. Rules 20 to 25 of the Panel's rules govern transfers of multicircuit appeals.[3]

This authority has been sparsely used. The first reported decision on transfer of appellate matters came in 1996.[4] The Panel considered two pending appeals, and after resolving a question of whether the petitions were properly filed, assigned to appeals randomly to the Seventh Circuit, one of the two circuits with pending appeals from the same NLRB decision. In 2003 the Panel considered four petitions for review of agency decisions pending in two circuit courts of appeal.[5] The Panel randomly selected the 9th Circuit in which to consolidate these petitions for review. The proceeding was initiated by the Panel filing notice of multicircuit petitions pursuant to 28 U.S.C.A. § 2112(a)(3).

In a nearly contemporaneous case, the Panel transferred appellate proceedings where 13 petitions for review were pending in 11 circuits.[6] The Panel transferred to the randomly selected Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals. Here, in an interesting development, the Eighth Circuit turned around and reassigned all the appeals to the D.C. Circuit.[7]

Because of its limitation to administrative appeals, this statute does not get frequent use. Because of the mechanistic approach to assignment, relying on a random draw, it is also not very taxing for the Panel.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See 28 U.S.C.A. § 2112(a). The statute is set forth in § 3:19.
See In re N.L.R.B., 936 F. Supp. 1091 (J.P.M.L. 1996).
Sempra Energy Resources v. F.E.R.C., 2003 WL 23019197 (D.C. Cir. 2003).
